captions.text:
You know what I didnít like about Django
Unchained?
What? The 4 or 500 uses of the n-word?

What? No. Wait a minute. Are we gonna hold
this movie about the slave era to our modern

political correctness standards? What were
the white people in the movie supposed to

call black people? Disappointments? Are we
gonna use something innocuous so that we donít
get any historical accuracy in our ears.

Well thereís a difference between historical
accuracy and overkill man. They used that

word, like, three times a sentence in that
movie,
Thatís not an exaggeration at all.

You wanna talk about historical accuracy,
letís talk about Jackie Brown, letís talk
about Pulp Fiction.
Okay, letís talk about ëem.

Those movies are both set in the 90ís and
shot in the 90ís, the single most PC era

thatís ever existed, and the n-wordís all
over both of those movies. I mean, in Pulp

Fiction Tarantino says the word like itís
a stutter. And he says it to Samuel L. Jacksonís
face. That guyís gotta have titanium balls.

I think people are just too sensitive about
words these days.

People are too sensitive about some words
these daysÖ but the n-word, theyíre not

being too sensitive. That word is f*ckiní
toxic, man. Thereís only one word more controversial
than that.
Which is?
(CENSORED)

Dude Ióyou do know this is all on camera
right. Like, I cannot believe you just said
that.

If Tarantino can say the n-word to Samuel
L. Jackson, then why canít I say the naughty
words and flaunt it?

That word isnít naughty, dude, that word
is apocalyptic. Besides, Iím sure that Sam
Jackson had a conversation with--

Yeah, ìSamî Jackson, like heís youíre
buddy.

Okay, Samuel L. Motherf*cking Jackson. The
point is, do you think he would have done
the movie if he was offended?
He certainly wasnít offended by the paycheck.

Dude, everybody worked for scale on that movie.
It was made for 8 million dollars and half
of that probably went to the gimp.

Oh, a gimp doesnít cost anything. Come on.
I can have a gimp here by 5 PM, with accessories.

The point is, about Django Unchained I didnít
like the scene where they were taking Django
to the mine.
What was wrong with that?

Well, everything. It feels tacked on, Tarantino
indulges his acting bug again playing an Australian

slave driver. The sceneís only there, so
it can pay off the horrible things Django
did.
Django was the hero...

Was he? Was he really? Let's remember heís
coming back to save his wife.
That's a noble thing...

Yeah, itís noble. But think about what he
has to do to save his wife. He transforms

into this method actor, becoming a black bounty
hunter so vile he makes Uncle Tom look like
Snow White.
Yeah, he had to convince Leonardo DiCaprio.

Right, but then even after he had convinced
DiCaprio and everybody else, he still lets

that other black guy get lynched, without
stopping it, even though Christoph Waltz is

there and offers to pay good money to save
the guy. And the only way that pays off is

if there's something that happens in the story
later on where he can then be vouched for

by slaves who can say, you know, heís not
with us, or heís not one of us.
The scene where he's being led to the mines...

Yes. You just allowed all this suffering and
let a man die a horrible death just in the

event you were being led away into a remote
mineÖ just in the event other slaves were

with you that could vouch for your storyÖ
and just in the event the white people believe

your story and let you goÖ then maybe it
would pay off and you could go see your wife

again. I say in the end, Django was the thing
he was pretending to be.

I say Iíd like to see you say that to a group
of black people.
I donít really know any black people.
Thatís racist.
You donít really know any black people either.

Yeah, but I don't go around telling everybody
about it.

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - Django Unchained
